Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: Robust Distributed Wind Power Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Harnessing wind energy is one of the pressing challenges of our time. The scale, complexity, and robustness of wind power systems present compelling cyber-physical system design issues. Leveraging the physical infrastructure at Purdue, this project aims to develop comprehensive computational infrastructure for distributed real-time control. In contrast to traditional efforts that focus on programming-in-the-small, this project emphasizes programmability, robustness, longevity, and assurance of integrated wind farms. The design of the proposed computational infrastructure is motivated by, and validated on, complex cyber-physical interactions underlying Wind Power Engineering. There are currently no high-level tools for expressing coordinated behavior of wind farms. Using the proposed cyber-physical system, the project aims to validate the thesis that integrated control techniques can significantly improve performance, reduce downtime, improve predictability of maintenance, and enhance safety in operational environments.

The project has significant broader impact. Wind energy in the US is the fastest growing source of clean, renewable domestically produced energy. Improvements in productivity and longevity of this clean energy source, even by a few percentage points will have significant impact on the overall energy landscape and decision-making. Mitigating failures and enhancing safety will go a long way towards shaping popular perceptions of wind farms -- accelerating broader acceptance within local communities. Given the relative infancy of "smart" wind farms, the potential of the project cannot be overstated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Robust Distributd Winder Power Engineering" project focused on new software techniques for rapidly prototyping novel embedded applications in the field of wind power. Due to the high investment cost of wind turbines, it is important to continuously monitor the health of turbines to prevent costly failures and reduce expansive unscheduled maintenance. Failure of a blade can cause damage in other turbine subsystems as well as neighboring facilities. Wind engineering researchers need to be able to rapidly experiment with novel techniques for monitoring turbines.  This project delivered a programming environment and runtime system named RTDroid -- this programming environment is based on the popular Android system used in phones and mobile devices. RTDroid extends Android to support real-time applications and modifies its interfaces to be suitable to control embedded devices installed in Wind Turbine. This required make substantial changes to the Android implementation, in fact, it required an entirely new virtual machine. Changes to the programming model were minimal allowing legacy code to be reused. The resulting system was deployed on Wind Turbine testbed and used to prototype a novel health monitoring application. This application is able to detect cracks in the blades of a turbine by detecting anomalies in the sound signature of blades. Thus it is possible to detect when a blade starts to show signs of stress. Several experiments conducted in the project's testbed validated that approach. The new programming model was found to be markedley easier to use than previous approaches that relied on programming custom made controls in the C programing language. In terms of technology transfer the health monitor was patented by one of the PIs, the RTDroid system was released in open source and is being commercialized.
